Mary, Gary & Lucy
Mary, Gary & Lucy
Notes on solving disputes between DM and player
Gywerd
Alef
Mary, Gary & Lucy
Preface
To some extend any roleplayer, anachronist, reenactor, cosplater, or steam punker is a nerd. They may focus extencively on history, religion, mythology, lore, clothing, crafting, architechture, animals, sourcebooks etc. Often it enriches roleplaying. But any party has a Mary the Contrary or a Gary
A Lucy (reference to Narnia - Lewis 1950) can be annoying, even when she's trying her best not to be. Maybe she doesn't really want to play, but does so to please the party. Or she has trouble comprehending the abstracts of the game.
A Gary (honorary reference to Gary Cygax, the co-inventor of Original D&D) is the player, who has read older sourcebooks extensively or has played D&D for decades. They know a lot about the game - and sometimes more than the DM about particular subjects. But to the DM and other players, this can become an substantial annoyance, when they frequently refer to different campaign settings, possibilities in earlier editions and old school adventures nobody else has ever heard of.
Mary the Contrary is a player, who wants to tweak the game - often disagrees with the DM - or does exactly the opposite of, what the DM had expected and planned for the session.
Sometimes you even encounter the übernerd, Gary the Contrary, that combine the traits of Gary & Mary the Contrary.
As DM you need to handle these challenges:
beßerwißer
flavour
sourcebooks, lore, races & classes from older editions
alternative backgrounds
exagerated creativity
lack of initiative
lack of participation
Adequate solutions ought to be based on
creativity
common sense
clear distinction between core rulebooks, other official sourcebooks and homebrew
interpretation of exisisting 5e rules
balancing RAW, RAI & RAF
Optional Feat Rule (PHB)
In order to achieve this, we need set some limitations:
New races must be Custom Lineages (TCoE p. 7) or variants of existing races using Custom Origin (TCoE p.8) - optimally as subclasses
New classes must be variants of exsisting classes - optimally as subclasses
Alternative backgrounds must be outlined in accordance with standard rules (DMG p.)
Anything from older editions must be adapted to 5e - and approved by the DM
